The Buddha said: First, why do we count the breath? Because the breath is light and easy to know. In the world,

people are all attached to the body and are unable to let go of the body to guard the mind. Moreover, the matters in the body are difficult to discern, and they all do not believe in the originally non-existent mind that does not cease.
Why is it said that the mind is empty?
Because of the inverted practice of the breath, one sees existence and non-existence, so the breath is first explained;
Gradually understanding the human mind, counting from the beginning, one attains the practice of the first meditation.
The Buddha said:
When sitting in meditation, one should have three concentrations.
What are the three concentrations?
First, concentration of the body;
second, concentration of speech;
third, concentration of the mind.
The cessation of pain and itching is the concentration of the body, the cessation of sound is the concentration of speech, and the cessation of mental thoughts is the concentration of the mind.
The cessation of thoughts is to accept and practice the constant mindfulness of the Way;
The cessation of sound is to cut off the four evils;
The cessation of pain and itching is not falling into craving.
When the mind is in cessation, the body, speech, and mind are in concentration, and one should establish the precepts and uphold them with the body and mind.
Upholding means not committing any offenses, and upholding the body and mind is called practice.
Practice means upholding the mind and practicing the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
The sÅ«tra says:
What is not recognized and what cannot be stopped is not recognizing in the breath and not being able to stop the mind from leaving when it goes.

In this way, one should diligently practice, exert effort, guard, sit upright, join the palms, lower the head, hold the mind, and place it in the center of the heart, falling into self-arising and ceasing.
One should recognize when the mind leaves, and having recognized it, one will be able to stop it and not fall into the hindrances.
The hindrances are in play, doubt, and listening to the six sense faculties, and this is not possible.
The Buddha said:
The mind counting the breath now does not alternate in counting the breath. What is the intention? The mind is for alternating practice.
The Buddha said:
The three concentrations have already been determined, the precepts should be in accordance with the Vinaya, for the way of the Dharma, loving practice of the Way.
Therefore, the sutra says:
Loving the way of the Dharma, practicing the Way, already sitting and practicing the Way.
In the latter part of the night, being startled and guarding the mind while eating, when it is time, at noon, in the west until evening, this is called the four guards.
One should be diligent and not separate from it, this is called hard work.
Midnight, sunrise, noon, and afternoon, this is called the four correct.
Reading sutras, walking meditation, circumambulating the stupa inside and out;
Observing one's own body, internally observing the five cessations, externally from head to toe, from toe to head, observing each and every part, what does it have?
All will become foul and rotten, falling apart joint by joint.
Originally, there is nothing that comes to be, and when it goes, it also ceases to exist and becomes nothing.
Reversing and reflecting, using the mind of counting, the mind still does not understand.
Seeing a dead person, contemplate from head to toe, whether sitting, standing, or eating, always keep it in mind to strengthen the mind, this is called counting contemplation.
When the contemplation of exhalation and inhalation ceases, one has already realized the cessation of the exhaustion of breath and its non-existence;
Calculating and contemplating, one knows that all people will eventually perish.
When the mind is already settled, one then knows emptiness.
Therefore, the sutra says:
First, diligence;
Second, counting contemplation;
Third, contemplation.
The Buddha said:
Contemplate one's own body, sometimes contemplate the bodies of others, and contemplate the body for calculation.
Contemplating the bodies of others is to contemplate the body of one's own mind being attached, and to contemplate the decay of others' bodies.
Sometimes one can contemplate one's own body, and also contemplate others' bodies.
What can be contemplated by oneself is to contemplate one's own body without attachment;
One can observe the bodies of others, but also observe the bodies of others without attachment.
Sometimes one cannot observe one's own body, nor can one observe the bodies of others.
As for not being able to observe one's own body, it is because one sees one's own body as fat, fair, and good-looking;
As for not being able to observe the bodies of others, it is also because one sees the bodies of others as fat, fair, and good-looking, with well-defined eyebrows and red lips.

When seeing fat, one should think of bloating; when seeing fair, one should think of the bones of a dead person; when seeing well-defined eyebrows, one should think of the color turning blue-black when a dead person is about to decay; when seeing red lips, one should think of the blood all decaying - what is there to crave?
As for observing one's own body with the mind as having thirty-two parts, counting hair, body hair, nails, teeth, bones, skin, flesh, and the five internal organs as eleven earth-related things;
tears, mucus, saliva, pus, blood, fat, marrow, sweat, and urine as seven water-related things;
warmth, and the digestive fire as two fire-related things;
Wind has twelve things;
These thirty-two things all come from earth, water, fire, and wind.
What is earth?
A person is born from the essence of grains, grains are earth, the mind is the seed, the essence and energy are the rain, and then the body is formed.
Seeking one piece of clothing and one meal is to nourish the energy and protect the host.
The human body is originally non-existent, so it is impermanent and will perish. By attaining the Way, one knows that the body is not the self.
Think that the body will not last long, and will surely die and decay;
The mind is the seed of a person, so guard the mind and be one-pointed.
A foolish person does not guard the mind and protect the spirit, but only nourishes the four limbs, deceived by the taste of form.
Thinking that the body is the self, they do not know that all evil arises from the body;
Eating and drinking greedily for taste, they fall into suffering;
Coming and going in birth and death without escape, suddenly encountering evil, the spirit goes empty, heading towards the path of good and evil;
The body dies and falls to the ground, decaying day and night.
They are also originally non-existent, but because of mental activity, a body is formed;
When dead, all return to earth. All things are also like this, all will pass away, this is impermanence.
People do not consider themselves, but have myriad thoughts, all not for one thing, this is suffering, the body dies and is discarded;
All things are also like this.
Extinction is already rebirth, birth is suffering again, then creating good and bad karma, not knowing where to go, this is non-self.
A practitioner should practice to end this.
If one does not understand the four kinds of impermanence, one will never attain the Way.
By considering oneself, seeing all dead and decayed things, knowing that people and objects are all non-existent, the mind then abides in stillness, and one can practice with joy;
Having attained practice, the mind then feels at ease.
Not leaving the five, the mind is one with the Way.
The Buddha said:
Contemplate the body, observe the hair and brain.
Contemplate that the hair originally has no existence, it is created through transformation and will all decay and fall out;
The brain is like congealed rice gruel, all of it will become foul and spoiled;
The eyes are just empty sockets, all the fluid comes out and the sockets are empty;
The ears are just flesh, all of them are pierced and leaking;
The nose and mouth are filled with mucus, all of it flows out and dissipates;
The tongue, throat, lungs, and liver are in the heart, and there is bad blood in the heart;
The liver, gall bladder, diaphragm, and spleen are attached to the stomach;
The kidneys are attached to the spine;
The stomach contains undigested food;ğŸ”½The large intestine has feces;
The small intestine has urine in the bubbles.

When the bowels move, the abdomen slightly increases and decreases, and when the body dies and the breath is exhausted, it will all become bloated and rotten, and the intestines, stomach, feces, and urine will be mixed together, and the foul smell is disgusting.
Below there is the buttocks meat, two shanks, and two feet, the flesh and muscles are gradually exhausted, the sinews and blood vessels are destroyed, and the bones are separated joint by joint.
The shanks and calves are firm, and the white thigh bones are like chariot spokes.
The hip bones are connected to the spine, the spine to the ribs, the shoulder bones to the elbows, arms, and hands. The skin and flesh rot away, and the bones fall apart.
The neck bones are connected to the skull. The flesh and blood dry up, and only the bones remain.

When the breath stops, it is called a dead person. The body becomes straight and no longer moves. When the wind leaves, the body becomes cold. When the fire leaves, yellow liquid flows out from the nine orifices. When the water leaves, the dead body no longer eats. When the earth leaves, after three or four days, the color turns to blue. Pus and blood flow out from the mouth, nose, ears, and eyes, which are red. The muscles and flesh decay, and the bones turn white. After a long time, they turn black and become ash and soil.
Looking outside the village at a smelly dead body, the bones of a dead person are like this. One's own body is also like this. They will all perish and become empty.
When exhaling, one knows emptiness. Knowing emptiness, one knows the body is empty.
Why is this?
Because one knows that life is near the emptiness of the breath.
The Buddha said:
The mind should first contemplate and think, extinguishing thoughts and waiting for the mind to naturally guard itself.
If the mind does not leave the body, one becomes an ascetic, waiting outside for myriad things.
Thoughts within are thinking, consciousness desires to extinguish thoughts and wait, thinking that things are impermanent and will perish, all are not mine, and I am also not the master of things.
When the mind thinks of death, what does it take with it when it goes?
It takes goodness, it takes unity, it must take the sutras, because doing much brings much joy.
The Buddha said:
This is your possession to take with you, the rest are all not mine.
The mind should recognize and remember:

What is the point of loving reunions that will inevitably end in separation? They all dissolve and decay. Thinking of them only confuses the mind, causes people to fall into wrongdoing, and will inevitably return to the body to guard purity and head towards the path of nirvana.
The Buddha goes from the one mind to the nine paths, contemplating the four colors will all be extinguished.
It is said that after a person dies for four or five days, about to rot and stink, the color turns to pure blue;
On the fifth and sixth days, pus and blood flow from the mouth, nose, ears, and eyes, bright red;
Later, the flesh decays, worms grow in the intestines and stomach, which then eat themselves, the skin dissolves and rots, the bones turn white, and after a long time, they turn black and become ash.
Clearly, earth, water, fire, wind, and space are not what the mind belongs to.

Since beginningless time, you have also been a person's wife, husband, or servant, and have also been an animal, a cow, a horse, an insect, or an elephant, suffering heavy burdens, and have been slaughtered, skinned, minced, or roasted by people.

Now as a human, you are again a person's wife, husband, or servant, and also take animals to slaughter, skin, mince, stab, or chop them. When your own body dies, you will all have to undergo this again.
Practitioner!
Have you ever seen a dead person?

When the breath stops, they become unconscious, their body stiffens and straightens, then rots and becomes foul-smelling and disgusting. Contemplate this and you will be afraid and not want to see it.
Why is it not afraid and single-minded?
Single-mindedness causes one to ascend to heaven and attain the path of nirvana.
The Buddha knows that the nine realms are all empty and nonexistent, so he returns to single-mindedness.

The practitioner urgently extinguishes thoughts, waiting to know nothing else, and then reaches the realm of emptiness, practicing emptiness everywhere, seeing the use but not dwelling on it, therefore not seeing.
The Buddha said:

The mind desires greed and thoughts are impermanent and decaying. Lust should be contemplated as opposed, anger should be contemplated as equanimity, and delusion should be contemplated as the basis. All practices are impermanent, and non-action is peaceful.
People do not know impermanence, and in the end they do not abandon greed, nor do they leave the path of the three lower realms.
All that exists in the world is like a dream. In a dream, one eats and sees good things, but upon waking, one does not see them.
All that exists in the world is like this. Birth ends in death, and as soon as it is formed, it is destroyed. It all returns to emptiness in the end. What is there to be greedy for?
People have wives, children, and property, and it is the same.
Why is it so?

When people engage in business and obtain money and profit, if they gather with their family and enjoy themselves, it is like a flock of birds gathering, but they are also impermanent. One day they will part and be gone, never to be seen again.
Even if there are worries and fears and myriad sufferings, the mind is in the midst of birth and death, accumulating sins day by day.

A wise person restrains themselves, has few desires, seeks only one garment and one meal, practices with a focused mind, does not seek a place to rest, always returns to guard the purity of the body, and cuts off seeking and contemplates emptiness.
He asked:
From what does the practice of guarding the mind and its root arise?
The Buddha said:
After the formation of heaven and earth, people came down from the fifteenth heaven, with a lifespan without premature death. Birth and death in the five paths arise from the six deteriorations.
When a person is born, the mind is originally good, without greed, love, pain, itching, thought, birth and death, or consciousness. It is deceived by the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth.
The eyes see colors, the ears hear sounds, the nose knows smells, the mouth knows tastes, the body knows cold, warmth, and roughness, and the mind creates ten things, forming the five aggregates;
The mind combines with consciousness, forming the six sense bases;
Based on creating good and evil actions, planting the seeds, from this there is old age, sickness, death, and birth in the five paths.

Seeking the Way, wanting to end birth and death, therefore guarding one's own mind, stopping the eyes from colors, stopping the ears from sounds, stopping the nose from smells, stopping the mouth from tastes, stopping the body from smoothness, ending the six sense bases, practicing contemplation, keeping the mind in thought, sitting in meditation to extinguish consciousness.
Those who attain the Way, the five aggregates are all extinguished;
Knowing the original non-existence, then contemplating emptiness, heading towards nirvana.
The reason for guarding the mind is:
The mind is the master of consciousness, creating evil, the six sense bases create misfortune, planting the roots of the five paths.
The practitioner diligently contemplates, guarding the four intentions, wanting to stop without evil, thoughts and ideas run.
What kind of person wishes to extinguish thoughts and ideas? They should practice that all activities are impermanent and cut off the ten things of the body.
The three of body, speech, and mind, from the five aggregates and six sense bases, cease.
The three concentrations are: speech having nothing to know is speech concentration, body having nothing to know is body concentration, mind having no further thoughts is mind concentration.
The Buddha said:
The Way has four essentials. Opening the seal of the realm leads to liberation.
What are the four?
First, knowing suffering, not returning to myriad things, is opening the seal to leave the three evil paths.
Second, knowing the body is not the body, then destroying the body and not loving it again, is opening the seal to leave the human realm and the sixth heaven.
Third, knowing impermanence and not returning to it, is opening the seal to leave the eighteen heavens.
Fourth, knowing emptiness and extinguishing emptiness, is opening the seal to leave the twenty-eight heavens.
Emptiness is extinguished and then falls into the Way.
The sÅ«tra says:
The one who realizes the path and attains liberation is called one who realizes suffering, emptiness, non-self, and impermanence.
Attaining liberation means attaining the four essential realms and attaining the first dhyÄna.
The upper seven heavens have no physical radiance.
Why is this?
Because practicing the path destroys the body.
